s.text: The correlation between the expression of these two markers therefore suggests the possibility that CCR6 might play a role in the development of aggregates of CD4 +T cells that are characteristically found in rheumatoid synovium.

It has been reported that CCR5 expression is upregulated in RA synovial fluid and synovial tissue T cells [ 10, 11, 12] and that CCR5 ? 32 deletion may have an influence on clinical manifestations of RA [ 13], suggesting that CCR5 might play an important role in RA.
No other correlations were detected (data not shown).
Furthermore, there were modest correlations between individual cells that expressed particular cytokines, such as IL-10, and certain chemokine receptor mRNAs.
Furthermore, there were modest correlations between individual cells that expressed particular cytokines and certain chemokine receptor mRNAs.
There were modest correlations between individual cells that expressed particular cytokine and chemokine receptor mRNAs.
Synovial tissues from three RA patients and peripheral blood mononuclear cells from two RA patients and a normal donor were analyzed.
Cytokine and activation marker expression by peripheral blood CD4 +memory T cells from RA patients and a normal donor
IFN-? and TNF-? were not expressed by normal peripheral blood CD4 +memory T cells, although they were expressed by RA peripheral blood CD4 +memory T cells.

Expressions of cytokine and activation marker mRNAs was also analyzed in 48 individual peripheral blood CD4 +CD45RO +T cells sorted from two RA patients and in 33 individual peripheral blood CD4 +CD45RO +T cells sorted from a normal donor.
TRANCE is known to be expressed by activated T cells, and can stimulate dendritic cells and osteoclasts [ 18].

Accordingly, correlation of cytokine and chemokine receptor expression might be important in delineating the function and potential means of accumulation of individual CD4 +memory T cells in the RA synovium.
By producing IL-10, they may exert an immunoregulatory function.
Of note, TRANCE-mediated activation of osteoclasts has recently been shown [ 19] to play an important role in the damage to bone found in experimental models of inflammatory arthritis.
